snippet: A law placing broad limits on the ability of local governments to control public health issues regarding restaurants has been ruled unconstitutional.
abstract: Ohio Judge Nancy Margaret rules that a state law placing sweeping limitations on local government's ability to control restaurants in the interests of public health violates the state constitution; law was initially aimed at a Cleveland ordinance banning restaurants and food makers from using industrial produced trans fats; ruling could have national implications on how local governments address public health crises in their communities.
lead_paragraph: A law placing broad limits on the ability of local governments to control public health issues regarding restaurants has been ruled unconstitutional.

headline.seo: Judge Rules Restaurant Law Unfair to Ohio Cities
headline.main: Judge Rules Restaurant Law Stifles Ohio Cities
headline.print_headline: Judge Rules Restaurant Law Stifles Ohio Cities
